items.title: Algeria passes law declaring French colonisation a crime
bullets: • Law declares France's colonisation of Algeria a crime and demands an apology and reparations

• The legislation lists the ‘crimes of French colonisation’, which include nuclear tests, extrajudicial killings, “physical and psychological torture” and “systematic plundering of resources”

items.title: ICE officer accused of excessive force, then sent back to work despite active probe
bullets: • Victor Mojica was caught on several cameras roughly pushing a woman into the hallway and then to the ground, as the woman screamed

• The incident at an immigration court in New York rapidly circulated online and prompted the Homeland Security Department to place Mojica on administrative leave – a rare instance of such leave being publicly announced
• The DHS Office of Inspector General ultimately decided — nearly two months later — that the incident did not merit a criminal probe

items.title: Why evolution rewarded ants that sacrificed protection
bullets: • Some ants thrive by choosing numbers over strength
• Instead of heavily protecting each worker, they invest fewer resources in individual armor and produce far more ants
• Larger colonies compensate with collective behaviors like group defense and coordinated foraging
• The strategy has been linked to evolutionary success and greater species diversity

items.title: What went right this week: treating the ‘untreatable’, plus more
bullets: • A world-first gene therapy has reversed previously untreatable blood cancers, scientists said this week
• The technique involves editing the genetic code of donor white T-cells to target cancer cells without attacking the patient’s body
• Alyssa Tapley, 13, was the first in the world to receive the treatment, known as BE-CAR7
